review_title: Backward management that hinders profitability and growth of the company
pros: FOC tickets, indefinite sub-load tickets, generally nice colleagues
cons:
There's a reason why CX has been in the red for the past 10 years and can never seem to get out of it. The answer is right under their noses but they are not able to take action due to it intertwine to their own fate.

Your top management are management trainees from Swire who spend their whole like in this rotation programme learning from people beneath them, therefore even when they have become old adults e.g. 40s, their mindset is still like a student, thinking of how to score an A to get a better next rotation. They do so by taking credit of their subordinates' work (who are local based employees) as they do not possess experience and skillsets to actually do real work that contributes to the company. When things go bad, they find a scapegoat, usually someone reporting into them.

This does makes you wonder what kind of management training they are getting in this very expensive lifetime programme where one never gets graduated and poor performers are simply dumped in outports (any roles not based in HKG), instead of being managed out. 

Their accommodation, bills, cars etc are all paid by Swire, which they take for granted like a fully sponsored lifetime holiday. Since they enjoy almost 100% savings of their salary from not having to pay for key things like housing mortgage that a normal person would, they are insensitive to employees needs in times of crisis, such as paycuts, and job security.

While they are a few that are good, majority, especially the ones who have been long breed into this programme have extremely backward management style (e.g. supervising by time in the office instead of deliverables, not open to use of basic technology like ms calendar ), discriminatory towards locals (they have a narrow minded believe that only foreigners are good and can be promoted so top talent locals keeps leaving the organization), and disregard for the law (they still operate like the mindset of emperors in the 18 century and think they have supreme power such that anyone must kowtow to them and any one who disagrees them even if its done professionally and in best interest of the company, is sent for execution). This also why it is so hard for them to innovate and grow..

The company says they are trying to be progressive, but alot is lip service and diplomatic answers with no real actions and commitment. The legacy mindset is too deeply ingrained to be changed without a complete wipeout of all the old school management who are parasites sucking the company dry.

pros:
-The pressure to outperform everyone and be a star performer is off, with the trade off being that the reward of being a star performer doesn't  exist. 

-Good role to commence a career in (your first year in professional work).

-Nice office to work in.
cons:
-Poor compensation package for this type of position against competitors and other industries. 

-Management is really hands off and not inspiring, creative, innovative nor energetic. The lower level staff are really driving the work, with upper management lacking the equivalent level of outputs at a commercial level. 

-Tangible career development and growth within the outport is not a reality. Your only chance of growth is in Hong Kong.

-An opinion - this company will be one of the last off the ranks out of this pandemic vs competitors. They are operating with up to 80-90% LESS capacity vs their competitors due to harsh restrictions in Hong Kong, supressing their outport schedule. They will miss the opportunity to soak up that pent up travel demand, and when they are ready, they will operate normally in an environment with high inflation rates and high fuel costs, hence load factors will never be that great nor at pre-pandemic levels.

review_title: Great people to work with, not so great company
pros:
The people are nice.
You get to enjoy free and heavily discounted ticket for you and your family.
Great work life balance
You are exposed to different culture and market and get to do duty trips to head office and countries that you take care of
cons:
1.Barely any chance to move upwards, especially if you are in local or regional office. They give lots of high and strategic positions in local, regional, and head office to swire management trainee staff. No matter how long you have worked there or how skilled you are, you will never win against the MTs. The MTs only stay in the position for certain period of time too, so lots of resources being used just to train and re-train them.

2.Very poor/slow decision making process and old school way of thinking - if you can see CX probably one of the last airline to innovate on something (one year into the pandemic, nothing has really been done apart from 'restructuring' - other airlines been innovating with flight credits, flight experience, flight meals delivery and so on but 0 from CX despite flying a very minimal schedule and earning next to nothing from passenger flights)

3. Firing people and cutting remaining staff salary as their easy way out of their issues - seems like they rarely think of other ways. Some departments resources were already stretched thin to begin with, with the restructuring, the remaining staff will definitely struggle and pushed to breaking point.

pros: Very professional flying outfit. Training is excellent. Lifestyle on 777 fleet is pretty good, with a decent prospect of overtime.
cons:
Hong Kong cost of living - particularly with a family. 

Industrial action (including a Training Recruitment ban) which has been ongoing for years now. 

Extremely poor lifestyle on A330 or 747 fleets. Max hours, short to medium haul, and a lot of two crew 'through the night' trips. 

Company treats staff as numbers, and routinely refuse to make concessions for even the most senior pilots. This is a reason why, as a new pilot, you will be given a 'Pilot's allowance' which hasn't seen an inflationary raise since 2008. 

Morale is incredibly low throughout the company and many people have already left. New contract for pilots is rumoured to be imminent with a 'take it or be fired' ultimatum.

Traditional '13th month' salary under threat because of extreme mismanagement over fuel hedging. No responsibility has been taken over this from management. 

Rostering practices agreement was ripped up and replaced by management years ago and we have seen no adequate replacement. Now they do what they want with us. 

Consistent, almost monthly, cuts to staff travel and medical benefits. A good example was when they placed Dragonair employees on equal footing with us for  staff travel. This even though they're a different company. 
From the DFO, "If you're here for the benefits, you're at the wrong company".
